full_reference: (4/1998) Tales from the Coast, 'Of Pine and Fir', The Lowestoft Sleeper Works,, Railway Bylines, ISSN:13602098, V.3, Issue:3, pp.94-105,
title: Tales from the Coast, 'Of Pine and Fir', The Lowestoft Sleeper Works,
description: THE FOLLOWING TEXT WAS PHOTOGRAPHED FROM AN UNRELATED MAGAZINE AND THEN CONVERTED TO TEXT USING MICROSOFT ONENOTE'S OCR CAPABILITY:- The Cardiff Railway was a minute concern even within the multitude of small railway companies dotted around the coal-bearing South Wales region in their independent heyday, from the mid-Victorian years until the enactment of Grouping in 1923, so it comes as something of a surprise that no less than 18 indigenous Cardiff locomotives were ceded to the Great Western Railway upon Grouping. Principally a docks network with never any pretensions towards passenger-carrying traffic, the Cardiff Railway was inaugurated in 1839 under the title of The Bute Docks Company by the Marquess of Bute, in which the speciallyconstructed Bute Docks on the Cardiff waterfront chieflyserved the Marquess' Bute mines. Subsequent opening of competing docks from the 1860s onwards removed an increasing proportion of the Bute Docks concern's revenueearning traffic with consequently diminishing viability for the small company. In 1886 it was reformed, under new ownership, as the rather pretentiously named Cardiff Railway and in apparent justification connecting links were forged with the larger regional systems; however it remained essentially a coal-moving business with all but some nine miles of the total 130 miles within the docks. At the outset motive power was of the fourfooted equine variety, though eventually steam locomotives were hired from the neighbouring TaffVale network to operate the railway more effectively. Following its reconstitution in 1886 the Cardiff Railway embarked upon ownership of its own haulage fleet, tank engines throughout and mainly of 0-6-0 configuration, with some 0-4-0s for the tighter dock areas together with a handful of the ubiquitous South Welsh 0-6-2 type for out-of-dock workings. The final batch of engines completed for the line was undertaken by Hudswell Clarke in 1920, comprising four sturdy six-coupled sad  dle tank locomotives numbered 14, 16, 17 and 32 (all CR engines were obtained from outside sources; the concern was far too small to venture into loco building on its own account). With Grouping taking place quite shortly after their commission, the four engines survived only a limited period in entirely original guise; typical G WR adornments such as safetyvalve bonnets quickly became obvious as did renumberings: 681-4 respectively and consecutively. Between 1926 and 1939 the four saddle tanks were fully rebuilt from the running plate upwards, utilising the Swindon Standard No. Il boiler to which pannier water tanks were attached, transforming both their appearance and their overall utility. A reduction in weight by almost four tons helped achieve the latter, notwithstanding a much enhanced coal capacity arrived at by the normal G WR procedure of extending the bunker rear panel in a 'bustle'. Numerous small differences in minor fittings appertained over the four-strong class of rebuilt engines, including various running-plate toolbox locations and buffer-head sizes. All four 0-6-0PTs were transferred into British Railway's ownership upon nationalisation in 1948, although they did not survive very long thereafter, being withdrawn in 1954-5.
